description.narrative: Development Advisory Services for direct support to upstream initiatives in UNDP's focus areas.
Development Advisory Services are established to provide Resident Representative with a rapid response capacity for direct support to upstream initiatives in UNDP's main focus areas.
independent political entity
The Country Programme of Albania under the Global Solar Water Heating Market Transformation and Strengthening Initiative (PIMS 3611)

participating-org.narrative: MPTF Albania One UN Coherence Fund

title.narrative: Programme of Albania for market strengthening and acceleration to promote solar water heating in Albania

description.narrative: Legal and regulatory framework on Global Solar Water Heating market created Enhanced awareness and capacity on SWH Increased demand for SWH by the availability of financing mechanisms Developed certification and quality control scheme

participating-org.narrative: MPTF Albania One UN Coherence Fund

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

provider-org.narrative: MPTF Albania One UN Coherence Fund
MPTF Albania One UN Coherence Fund
MPTF Albania One UN Coherence Fund

description.narrative: The total installed SWH capacity and annual sale.

comment.narrative: 33,000 m2 of installed collector area in 2005 with 7,000 m2 of new SWH capacity installed in 2005 with the expected 5% annual growth.

The adoption of the recommended legal and regulatory changes to promote sustainable SWH market development. Materials for public awareness raising as well as for training of building designers developed and/or adapted into Albanian conditions and made available in printed and electronic format. Enhanced awareness of the key financial sector stakeholder and local suppliers on the specific characteristics and financing opportunities in the SWH market. A certification and quality control scheme applicable for Albanian conditions and enhanced capacity of the supply chain to offer products and services promoting sustainable SWH market. The reporting framework and arrangement for the SWH market monitoring established.

Efforts during reporting period have been focused on supporting Ministry of Energy and Industry to progress with finalization of the RES Action Plan (with a specific target for solar energy), revision of RES Law/its secondary legislation to implement the Solar Chapter; supporting municipalities of Tirana, Elbasan, Shkoder, Sarande, Orikum, Gramsh and Fier with technical assistance and demonstration projects to justify the solar obligation’s ordinances to request SWH systems in each and every new public building and the ones going through a major renovation; on the job trainings for monitoring and maintenance of installed solar thermal systems; monitoring programs for hot water consumption and efficiency of big SWH systems; efforts to detail the EE/RES fund or other financing models, like NAMAs; opening of the assistance in the area of standards for EE and solar energy in social buildings, etc. A series of capacity building activities and awareness raising held on technology of SWH with several municipalities/communes alongside the south coast of Albania; During the reported period different promotion materials such as leaflets, fast facts, posters, 2015 wall calendar are prepared and distributed; Project webpage was transferred to UNDP’s one (www.al.undp.org) updated on regularly bases, while project’s activities were shared to some other social medias like Facebook, twitter, etc. Regular articles written and published to several newspapers and magazines.

The development of recommendations for the ope-rationalization of the EE/RES Fund. The drafting of a publication based on the lessons learnt and experiences of the studies produced during the Project. The drafting of a publication with the findings from the monitoring of the pilot projects. Other pilot projects designed and implemented in cooperation wit local governments. TE as per the requirements of GEF. Development of a policy SEA for the SHPPs sector. Feasibility of EMIS use in the local municipalities and of three pilot builings. Upscale through a proposal at national level under the GCF.
The strategy, statute and operational manual for the EE/RES Fund are provided.

Further follow-up, consultations, analysis and elaboration of the initiated legal and regulatory measures to promote the solar thermal applications at the national and municipal level; Awareness raising and training of the key stakeholders on the practical implementation of the secondary legislation of the RES law; Trained students, building designers and other key professionals to consider SWH as an option in the design of new buildings and renovation of the existing ones; Implementation of different pilot projects in collaboration with the Municipalities; Assessment and Report Compilation, Consultation and Launching Event of the SEA report for the SHPPs; Finalization of feasibility studies for the selected projects, facilitating their financing through existing EE/RE facilities in Albania and upscale the project at the national level to enable financing through the Green Climate Fund.

RES law got approved, February, 2017. Work has started for the secondary legislation. SWH pilot projects installed in Durres, while technical projects are ready for tendering in 9 other institutions in Vlora, Himara, and Saranda. A SWH design manual is provided for the purpose of the university curricula of the scientific masters under the Energy and Environmental faculties; The SEA of SHPPs is drafted; The Concept Note for the Energy Efficient Public Buildings for GCF is drafted. The SWH systems are about to be installed in 5 different public buildings in Saranda and Himara. The on-the-job training of municipal officers in charge with development policy and environment from Durres Municipality on the issue of EMIS and energy efficiency is carried out. 4 Feasibility Studies are undertaken for the needs of the Durres Municipality in terms of energy efficient public buildings. The training of students of scientific masters from the polytechnic university on the subject of SWH design is successfully organized. The publication on "Best practices from the SWH Project" is realized.

description.narrative: Improving coverage and management effectiveness of marine and coastal protected areas (PIMS 4255)

title.narrative: Mid-Term Review of Improving coverage and management effectiveness in marine and coastal protected areas project

description.narrative: Improved bio-geographical representation of MCPAs Improved management arrangements for MCPAs based on clear institutional responsibilities and development of capacities.
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Strategic Plan for Albania’s Marine and Coastal Protected Areas 2. Two proposals for new MPA establishment 3. Legal environment for MCPA management 4. Adequate management of buffer zone for MPA 5. Guideline for adequate management of buffer zone for MCPA 6. Management Boards at MCPAs 7. # of agreements or memorandum of cooperation/ understanding MPA/PA issues 8. Management effectiveness tools for MCPAs 9. Number of manuals/ guidebooks prepared as a resource for imparting further training 10. Funding of Karaburuni-Sazani MPA 11. Status of the seagrass Posidonia oceanica along Karaburuni and Albanian Ionian coast

comment.narrative: No Strategy for Marine Protected Areas No Management Board at MPA No Management Effectiveness tool for MCPAs in place

1. Public hearing and participatory process for the approval of the Management Plan for Karaburun-Sazani 2. Implementing priority management actions according to the Management Plan for Karaburun-Sazani 3. Production of the Business Plan for Karaburun-Sazani 4. Assist MPA Administration in enforcement and control mechanism through Micro Capital Agreement arrangement with local institutions and NAPA 5. Strengthening of the MPA administration with training and equipment 6. Assistance of the MoE for the new MPA designation, Porto Palermo 7. Produce a booklet with information on MCAPs 8. Produce of the Manual of Training of Trainers on MCPAs management 9. Training on management effectiveness and produce an online tracking tool on management effectiveness 10. Production of the photo album on Karaburun-Sazani MPA

1. Public hearing and participatory process for the approval of the Management Plan for Karaburun-Sazani is completed. 2. Micro Capital Agreement arrangements with local institutions and NAPA are signed to assist MPA Administration in enforcement 3. Equipment for MPA administration are provided. 4. Assistance of the MoE for the new MPA designation, Porto Palermo is provided. 5. Booklet with information on MCAPs is produced 6. Manual of Training of Trainers on MCPAs management is produced 7. Application online on tracking tool on management effectiveness is produced and provided.

1. Assisting the National Agency of protected Areas for the improvement of the Legislative and regulatory framework 2. Conducting an assessment of ecosystem services in MPA K-S 3. Assessment of the zoning and habitat mapping of the coastal and marine protected areas 4. Assistance on management and capacity building for the Marine Park administration 5. Inspecting, law enforcement and monitoring of the marine park 6. Information, communication and public awareness of the MPA Karaburun-Sazani 7. Produce a video documentary on the values of the MPA Karaburun-Sazani 8. MCPAs monitoring and performance evaluation through METT 9. Implementing the priority action as per Management Plan for MPA Karaburun-Sazani 10. Providing synergies and cross sectorial coordination by regular meetings of the Management Committee of the MPA K-S

1. The law on PAs is drafted and currently UNDP is assisting the National Agency of Protected Areas (NAPA) on the consultation process 2. A report on ecosystem services in MPA K-S is completed and shared with the stakeholders and the Ministry of Environment and NAPA. 3. Assessment report on the zoning and of the coastal and marine protected areas is finalized and habitat maps are produced 4. The Marine Park administration is assisted with logistic and training on the management of the MPA. 5. MoU is signed with the Nation Agency on Protected Areas for the law enforcement hiring 4 additional rangers and monitoring of the MPA. 6. Under the MoU with NAPA activities of public awareness are conducted, information is distributed through the application iVlora and an information center is under establishment in the MPA Karaburun-Sazani 7. A video film on the values of the MPA Karaburun-Sazani is produced 8. MCPAs monitoring and performance evaluation is done through METT. There is a significant improvement of the management of the MCPAs 9. In close cooperation with the Regional Agency of PAs and the NGO NCA some priority actions in MPA Karaburun-Sazani habe been carried out. 10. Two meetings of the Management Committee of the MPA K-S have been held (January, September 2016) providing synergies and cross sectorial coordination
1. Establish an information center in Radhime, Vlora 2. Make operational the Info-Center 3 Develop Marine and Coastal Protected Areas Phase II 4. Start implementation of Phase II

1. The Info Center in Radhima is established 2. An NGO is assisting the administrative unit in Vlora for funtionaning the Info Center 3. The Regional Administration of PAs is assisted on the implementation of the management plan 4. The phase II of the project is developed and ready for implementation

description.narrative: To improve coverage and management effectiveness of Albanias marine and coastal protected areas
Area under protection as Coastal and Marine Protected Areas

comment.narrative:
100236 ha
existing coastal protected areas mainly coastal wetlands

An additional 1257082 ha declared as Albanias first MPA Karaburun Sazani
An additional 3500 ha in the process of being declared as MPAs Rodoni CapeLalzi Bay and PaganeKepi i Stillos

in line with the Strategic Plan for the MCPAs two other MPAs Porto Palermo and Cape of Rodoni are in the process to be proclaimed Assessment and public hearing are conducted For Porto Palermo is foreseen the status Natural Park and the documents for proclamation National Park an area with surface of 206775 ha are being circulating among the line ministries

description.narrative: Enabling environment created for revision of the existing MCPA status facilitated by the project

comment.narrative: Weak capacities for revising MCPAs status
At least 2 MoE experts capable for conducting revision of MCPA according the international standards

During the project implementation curricula and training modules on marine biodiversity conservation and management are produced and published They are reference material to several training organized in the country also from the National Agency of Protected Areas NGOs and others which focused better knowledge on MCPAs issues

description.narrative: Improvement in management effectiveness of KaraburuniSazani MPA measured through change in METT scores

comment.narrative: Baseline METT Score as percent of Total Possible Score is 17
Target is 4555

The assistance to the National Agency of Protected Areas NAPA and the Ministry of Environment is ongoing in frame of management effectiveness of PAs The METT tool is applied and assessment of management effectiveness of PAs including KaraburuniSazani MPA is performed for 2015 METT score for KaraburunSazani is 47The methodology and assessment forms were adopted and incorporated in an online platform httpwwwmettundpal The website was further enriched with info and reporting entries from the NAPA pertinent to visitors survey illegal activities nature and culture monument etc Finally the web based METT tool is established and functional allowing links with project website and other relevant sites contributing to make this assessment tool more user friendly website pattern navigation structure etc

description.narrative: Increased Systemic Institutional and Individual capacities for establishing and managing an MCPA system

comment.narrative:
See UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard in Annex 5 for baseline
Systemic 37
Institutional 29
Individual 38

See UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard in Annex 5 for target
Systemic 90
Institutional 87
Individual 95

Systematic 40 67
Institutional 36 58
Individual 43 57
Compared with 2014 UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard for MCPA shows an increase of 27 for systematic 22 for institutional and 14 for individual level There are development in legislation strategies and programmes A new institution is established National Agency for Protected Areas which shows the political will towards Protected Areas and will help on building consensus among all institutions and stakeholders capacity to mobilize information and knowledge and capacity to monitor evaluate report and learn Compared to the baseline there is an increase of about 30

description.narrative: Improved biogeographical representation of marine and coastal protected areas MCPA
Clearly demarcated buffer zones in existing 9 coastal PAs with specific guidance on permissible activities for inclusion in the Management Plan

comment.narrative:
No buffer zones defined
No Management Plans in place
Buffer zones and permissible activities defined

The management planning for the MPA Karaburun Sazani and the buffer zoning roadmap are developed Buffer zone protocols and rules are being provided as respective management arrangements
In addition the management plan for Porto Palermo MPA has also developed the site zoning and site boundaries with due attention in the buffer area as well The zoning process has started in the meantime for the Cape of Rodoni

description.narrative: Clearly demarcated buffer zones in KaraburuniSazani MPA with specific guidance on permissible activities included in the Management Plan

comment.narrative: No buffer zones defined
Buffer zones and permissible activities defined

Assessment report on marine and coastal areas buffer zone is finalized including guidelines recommendations on setting up buffer zones for MPAs
The integrated management planning process Karaburuni Sazani developed with significant participatory approach has considered the buffer zone

description.narrative: Legal Instrument establishing MPA at KaraburuniSazani 1257082 ha

comment.narrative: No Legal Instrument
Legal Instrument is approved by the Council of Ministers

The law on biodiversity is revised
A new law on PA is under development accomplishing a combined review of all legal acts pertinent to environment conservation and management possible models mechanisms for MCPA administration revenues mechanisms changes with establishment of NAPA National Agency for Protected Areas as the biggest institutional development taking over the management of PA with direct dependence from the Minster of Environment splitting the management of protected areas form the forestry service structure

description.narrative: Legal Instrument incorporates best practice in design of such an instrument and can serve as a model for declaration of future MPAs

comment.narrative: There are no MPAs in Albania and therefore no examples of a legal instrument establishing an MPA
Legal Instrument for KaraburuniSazani MPA is developed as a model for future MPAs

The roadmap is prepared for the MCPA legal frame and recommendations to improve legislation and approximate it with EU directive
In additions the PA law is paying due attention on all latest institutional progress and development of relevant sector tourism activities zoning enforcement environmental inspectorates fisheries inspectorates the Coast Guard etc

description.narrative: Process of identification of additional MPAs at Rodoni CapeLalzi Bay and PaganeKepi i Stillos has begun

comment.narrative: Currently the adjacent areas have a protection status as CPAs only
Technical and scientific work for realizing designation of these areas is complete and political consultation process has been initiated

Processes for the designation of two additional MPAs Porto Palermo and Cape of Rodoni are progressing well According to the SPMCPA the two priority areas to be proclaimed are Porto Palermo not Pagan Kepi Stillos and Rodoni Cape
Ecologic evaluation public hearing organized with MoE relevant document for designating these sites as well as meetings with local stakeholders including informative materials and posters are accomplished
The draft Decision of Council of Ministers for Porto Palermo foresees the status Natural Park for a surface of 206775 ha It is planned to be proclaimed within 2015

description.narrative: Strategic Plan for Albanias Marine and Coastal Protected Areas SPMCPA

comment.narrative: No Strategic Plan has been developed for this subsystem of the national PA system
SPMCPA is developed and approved by the Interministerial Council or the Council of Ministers
The updated Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan is approved by the government and the SPMCPA is taken into consideration and incorporated in the document

description.narrative: Improved management arrangements for MCPAs based on clear institutional responsibilities and development of capacities
Aware inhabitants and stakeholders adjacent to the MPA and countrywide of MBD values

comment.narrative:
No means and tools available at local level to deliver information to stakeholders
No media coverage and no website for the targeted site Local media radio and TV has never run programme on MCPA and or MBD values

At least 3 dedicated programmes on MCPA and MBD conservation are mediatised per yearby EoY 5
All school children in Orikumi and Vlora are fully aware of globally important biodiversity in the KS MCPA by EoY 5

3
There have been produce a short documentary for the MPA site and several public awareness activities celebration of significand days such as 22nd May 2nd February 5 June etc The Environment Film Festival has conducted its 3rd edition in Albania The project has been actively part focusing on marine biodiversity films and involving the local schools
Awareness campaign is being conducted as part of implementation of the Management Plan in KaraburunSazani MPA
Knowledge and information is also produced and delivered in scope of new MPA designation processes Porto Palermo and Cape of Rodoni through workshops and posters

description.narrative: Gap between funding needs of KaraburuniSazani MPA and available funds

comment.narrative: Gap to be assessed by end of 1st year
At least 50 of funding needs are being met

The priority actions taken from the MP document are duly addresses A Micro Capital Grant Agreement is signed with INCA addressing the financial gap in funding priority management actions of the MCPA KaraburunSazani which will capture design and establish the buoys system repair and maintenance of some moles drafting and implement the code of conduct for the observation of wildlife updating inventory and monitoring of caves assess the situation of underwater objects fishing capacity assessment awareness packages and tourist products training etc
The Business Plan for MPA KaraburunSazani is under preparation
The NAPA has meantime sustained the government efforts and is providing government funds for accomplishing management action and conservation measures at MCPA KaraburunSazani

description.narrative: Increased understanding of the fish resources of the MPA

comment.narrative: Very limited studies on fish resources for the targeted area s
At least 3 site diagnoses missions and reports for KS MCPA deep insights fishery crosssectorial studies scoping the management and conservation of this sector

3
There are three mission accomplished in cooperation with Conservatoire du Littoral assessing the habitats and species on the target area including fish populations
The reports are delivered and taken into consideration for the Management Plan preparation of MPA KaraburunSazani

description.narrative: Interinstitutional agreements on management of marine and landbased threats to MCPAs

comment.narrative: At least 2 official agreements or memorandum of cooperation understanding between relevant ministriesinstitutions

2
MoU are continuing to be implemented with the Municipality of Orikumi and Regional Agency of PA with focus collection data and info on illegal activities
Monthly reports by Municipality of Orikum and Regional Agency of PA deliver to the Ministry of Environment
MoU Micro capital Grant Agreement with an Albanian NGO INCA is in place for the implementation of priority actions in KaraburunSazani MPA as per management plan
Cooperation and synergies include Prefecture of Vlora Commune Center Regional Directory of Environment of Vlora Coastline National Agency NGOs
Synergies and logistic are ensured with National Agency for Protected Areas NAPA recently established February 2015 for the protection and conservation of marine biodiversity

description.narrative: Management Boards at MCPAs

comment.narrative: At least 2 MCPAs have Management Boards

2
There is organized another MC meeting during reporting period 5th MC 27 January 2015 focusing and discussing the site management plan project progress main problems and other progress mainly management plan document and priority actions as well as financial issues The project plan for 2015 is discussed and approved at the Management Committee

description.narrative: Management effectiveness of existing 9 CPAs is being tracked

comment.narrative: Baseline METT Scores as percent of Total Possible Score to be estimated by the end of 2nd year
Progress in METT scores assessed annually thereafter

9
Regional training workshop on METT accomplished on 16th December 2014
METT assessment results are
PN Korab Korit 44
Shebenik 67
NP Lure 44
NP LLogara 67
Bize Martanesh 44
NP Valbona 67
NP Tomorri 67
NP Kune Vaini 56
Porto Palermo 44
NP Mali i Dajtit 67
NP Karavasta 78
Fushe Kuqe Ishem67
NP Hotove 56
The score for MPA KaraburunSazani increased from 39 to 45 attesting for the efforts made in enforcement and management of the site
The project is developing a user friendly electronic format for METT

description.narrative: Number of manuals guidebooks prepared as a resource for imparting further training

comment.narrative: Very limited
6 training modules

6
Training curricula and modules on marine biodiversity conservation and management are developed A number of trainings and workshop has been organized during 20132014 involving more than 45 local specialists MCPA administration as well as 5 experts from the MoE The final training workshop was held on August 2014
A Manual on Training on Integrated Management of MCPAs is published
Other publications are on the way include buffer zone guideline a passport for the Albanian MCPA and a photo album for KaraburunSazani MPA values

title.narrative: Albanian Mine Action and Ammunition Disposal

description.narrative: Coordination and monitoring of humanitarian mine action, hotspots clearance and ammunition stockpile disposal in Albania

participating-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

title.narrative: Third Party Cost Sharing Agreement with Germany
Albanian Mine Action and Ammunition Disposal

description.narrative: The project is aiming to improve ammunition disposal and clearance standards through coordination and monitoring of clearance of the ammunition hotspots.

participating-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

description.narrative: independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

provider-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

description.narrative:
Improved EOD and quality management standards in line with the International Mine Action Standards.
A public awareness and risk education scheme running in the affected areas.
A victim assistance system in place to encompass all ERW/AXO survivors.

comment.narrative: The current government demilitarization plan is running solely as a military operation without considerations on safety measures and socio-economic impact on civilian population.

Certification and handover of about 400,000 sqm of cleared UXO/ERW hotspots in Gjeroven, Palikesht and Mbreshtan in Berat, Klos and Suç in Diber, Gerdec and Laç. About 28,000 community members living around the highly contaminated hotspots are educated and aware about the ammunition threat. About 100 amputee survivors are fitted with either new prostheses or repairs and needs and status of at least 80% of ERW/AXO victims throughout Albania is documented. Albania’s Annual Transparency Reporting obligations to the international disarmament conventions are timely fulfilled.

Completed the certification and handover of about 485,557 sqm of cleared UXO/ERW hotspots in Gjeroven, Palikesht and Mbreshtan in Berat, Gerdec icluding the five former military ammonitions depot in Murrash, Shkumbin in Elbasan,Macukull in Burrel and Selite, Shermill in Tirana.

Certification and handover of about 787,775 sqm of cleared and certified (41.5 % of total identified hotspots areas) in Picar and Kordhoc in Gjirokastra, Gjeroven and Mbreshtan in Berat, Klos in Burrel , Gerdec Laç and Sinanaj in Tepelene. Additionally, the project will conduct inspections and land certifications as free of ammunitions and safe for further use, of five former military depots and tunnels that stored ammunitions in Borizane-Kruje, Vertop-Berat, Qafe Molle 1- Tirane and Labinot and Mengel-Elbasan.
About 28,000 community members living around the highly contaminated hotspots are educated and aware about the ammunition threat. About 100 amputee survivors are fitted with either new prostheses or repairs and needs and status of at least 80% of ERW/AXO victims throughout Albania is documented. Albania’s Annual Transparency Reporting obligations to the international disarmament conventions are timely fulfilled.

Completed the certification and handover of about 824,386 sqm of cleared UXO/ERW hotspots in Gjeroven, and Mbreshtan in Berat, Gerdec, Lac, Klos, Picar and Kordhoc in Gjirokastra including the four former military ammunitions depot in Zaranike-Elbasan, Poshnje in Berat, Nuaj-Kruje and Qafe Molle-1 in Tirana.

Certification and handover of about 671,707 sqm of cleared and certified in Picar and Kordhoc in Gjirokastra, Qafe Shtame, Suc in Burrel , Sinanaj in Tepelene, Jube-Sukth in Durres. Additionally, the project will conduct inspections and land certifications as free of ammunitions and safe for further use, of five former military depots and tunnels that stored ammunitions in Borizane-Kruje, Vertop-Berat and Berzhite in Tirana. Community liaison, public awareness and risk education of local communities living around the affected areas in Gjirokaster, Tepelene, Durres, Burrel, Skrapar and Librazhd.
About 12,500 community members living around the highly contaminated hotspots are educated and aware about the ammunition threat. About 100 amputee survivors are fitted with either new prostheses or repairs and needs and status of at least 80% of ERW/AXO victims throughout Albania is documented. Albania’s Annual Transparency Reporting obligations to the international disarmament conventions are timely fulfilled.

Completed the clearance and certification of about 52,755 sqm of cleared UXO/ERW hotspots in Kordhoc and Picar in Gjirokastra. About 8,500 community members living around the highly contaminated UXO hotspots are educated and aware about the ammunition threat. About 80 amputee survivors are fitted with either new prostheses or repairs. 25 ERW/AXO survivors and their family members are assisted with vocational training programme. Albania’s 2016 Annual Transparency Reporting obligations to the international disarmament conventions are timely fulfilled.

description.narrative: Programme effectiveness enhanced for achieving results

UNDP's key development approaches fully integrated into UNDP programme and project for more durable results.Programme effectiveness enhanced for achieving results at all levels through quality criteria and quality assurance processes.

description.narrative: Validate the governance indicators of the sectorial strategies that were not approved in the first phase, with the NSDI advanced document

comment.narrative: Draft National Strategy for Development and Integration not approved for 2014-2020

Approval of NSDI within 2015 Preparation of a road map on how the SDG governance indicators should be followed up in the monitoring process Finalization of a case study on governance in Albania to share at the global level, the progress achieved, the importance and commitment towards governance as a strategic priority, and the Government’s intent to institutionalize the measuring of progress in this area as a contribution to the development of sustainable development goals

Approval of NSDI - ongoing process. Preparation of a road map on how the SDG governance indicators should be followed up in the monitoring process - Completed Finalization of a case study on governance in Albania to share at the global level, the progress achieved, the importance and commitment towards governance as a strategic priority, and the Government’s intent to institutionalize the measuring of progress in this area as a contribution to the development of sustainable development goals- Completed.
Technical support in putting in place a standardized coordination process at policy, program and project level, for both implementation and monitoring of the Integrated Sector Approach Mechanism
Two local consultants hired to work in a team with three EU consultants. First draft of the IPMG Policy Document completed by Nov 2016.

Continue the UNDP technical support with two local consultants aiming to put in place a standardized coordination process at policy, program and project level, for both implementation and monitoring of the Integrated Sector Approach Mechanism.

At the end of March 2017, another team of Experts from EU Delegation was expected to support the DDFA and Line Ministries mainly to expand the IPMG Mechanism with TA and NSP preparation. Both Local Experts will be a bridge support on this process and continue to assist the Technical Secretariats and DDFA to enforce and expand the IPMG Mechanism.

description.narrative: 1. New Social Protection and Inclusion Strategy, and ME Frameworks developed in a participatory way 2. Number of new laws and secondary legislation supported to ensure conformity with the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. 3. Number of municipalities planning, budgeting and providing gender sensitive social services to most at risk populations 4. Number of policies and plans on social services developed or improved with participation of Civil Society Organizations and marginalized groups 5. Number of regional coordination committees established for participatory social impact assessment 6. Criteria and guidelines in place for adapting social and public services to the specific needs of Roma/Egyptian populations

comment.narrative: 1. National social protection and social inclusion strategies due to expire in 2013 2. No laws and secondary legislation in place; concept of accessibility not understood as a cross-cutting issue 3. Number of Local Government units with inclusive social policy services in place is not known 4. No regional coordination committees for participatory social impact assessment 5, No Criteria and guidelines in place for adapting social services to the specific needs of Roma/Egyptian populations

1. Social Inclusion Policy Document 2015-2020 (including Indicators, Baselines and Targets for Social Inclusion Policies 2014-2020) finalized and endorsed by the government 2. Social exclusion profiles and policies for PWD and Roma developed, 3. By-laws of the law on Inclusion of and Accessibility for Persons with Disabilities elaborated through consultative process 4. Social Housing Strategy/ action plan (from social inclusion perspective) developed and endorsed by the government. A set of appropriate tools for the implementation and monitoring is in place 5. At least 2 demonstrative projects developed and implemented to accommodate the needs of persons with disabilities for education and integration

1. The secondary analysis of the 2011 Census re. PwD, Roma Egyptians, Youth, Elderly completed launched in 2015 with INSTAT. 2. Social exclusion profiles on Roma Egyptians, PwD; Victims of Trafficking, Elderly completed published. 3. Albanian legislation review for compliance with the CRPD other recently adopted legislation. 4. Policy paper for the transformation of the "Ndihma Ekonomike" into a social re-integration programme. 5. 4 new by-laws for the implementation of the Law on Inclusion of Accessibility for Persons with Disabilities: 6. 2 demonstrative projects for PWD other vulnerable groups - Tirana Institute of Deaf Students and Lushnja Development Centre finalised
1. National Action Plan on PwD 2. The new law on Social Housing 3. Housing Needs Assessment in the newly established local government units

1. Social Housing Strategy 2016 – 2026 developed and endorsed by the government 2. National Action Plan on PwD 2016 – 2020 developed and endorsed by the government 3. Housing Needs Assessment of vulnerable groups in the 61 newly established municipalities

description.narrative: 1.Operational plan in place and at least 2 new measures designed. 2. Self-employment measure designed. 3. Feasibility study carried out. 4. Elements of quality assurance identified. 5. Updated national list of occupations in place and occupational descriptions finalized.

comment.narrative: 1. 7 employment promotion measures currently implemented by NES; however, no operational plan in place. 2. No self-employment measure in place. 3. Several pilots carried out, however, no nation-wide model of work-based learning in place. 4. Elements of quality assurance piloted; however, no standards, tools and mechanisms implemented system wide. 5. National list of occupations established in 2009. 200 occupational descriptions elaborated. Over 320 remaining.

1. Operational plan of employment promotion measures developed and at least 2 new measures designed 2. Self-employment programme designed 3. Feasibility study on work-based learning models carried out 4. Models of quality assurance assessed and discussions on an Albanian model of quality assurance commence among relevant actors. 5. National list of occupations updated and occupational descriptions developed for all occupational levels.

1. Operational plan for 2016 developed, encompassing 5 new/revised employment promotion measures. 2. Self-employment programme designed 3. Feasibility study on work-based learning models delayed due to a similar study carried out by the National Agency on VET and Qualifications. Study on private sector incentives/disincentives for participation in work based learning carried out in 2015. 4. Work on models of quality assurance commenced, and research shared with relevant stakeholders. 5. National list of occupations updated and 115 occupational descriptions completed by the end of 2015.

comment.narrative: 1. No legal package proposed in alignment with the Istanbul requirements 2. Functioning of CCRs in 56% of municipalities 3. 2016 perceptions from ‘Fjale Burri’ study; 65% of men and boys 85% of girls

1. Parliamentary Commissions and Women Parliamentary Alliance made use of the proposed legal package to feed the legislative reform in general and justice reform in particular 2. 27 out of 61 municipalities have CCRs.
1. 6 new CCRs operational; 2. 65% of men and boys and 85% of girls believe a man should never rise his hands against a woman

1. 5 new CCRs established and 6 other municipalities the existing CCR mechanisms are further consolidated and expanded 2. CMD on standardized services of the national telephone helpline to GBV victims 3. Innovative campaign on GBV developed by young boys and girls as agents of change reached out to a big audience though the social media.
4 CCRs established in new municipalities A number of laws related to GBV improved in accordance with international standards 65% of men and boys 85% of girls
4 CCRs already established. A set of legal recommendations sent to Parliament in the frame of the justice reform package.

description.narrative: 1. Number of self-employment opportunities created for women; 2. 2015 perception study on gender equality and women’s successful integration into the labor market

comment.narrative: 1. Women represent 43.4% of labor force and own 28.5% enterprises; 2. Women literacy on economic, property and family rights is inconsiderable;

1. 4 self-employment opportunities created in four regions of the country for particular poor, marginalized and vulnerable women, particularly the ones that are de jure or de facto heads of households; 2. Women from semi-rural and rural areas, interest groups/women NGOs in 6 regions in the country are literate on their economic, property and family rights.

1. 58 women were identified in four regions for the establishment of local entrepreneurship out of whom 29 women were trained on medical and forest fruits processing and a processing center for such products was established; increased women’s orientation towards private initiatives to self-employment; and presenting products in the national and international fairs. 2.Economic literacy program in 5 regions reached out to over 170 local community vulnerable women and relevant state and non-state

1. 4 self-employment opportunities created in four regions of the country for particular poor, marginalized and vulnerable women, particularly the ones that are de jure or de facto heads of households;

1. Four business plans were developed and four cooperation agreements between women and local authorities were established in four semi-rural areas. 2. 88 women from these semi-rural regions fully employed. 3. families of 88 women benefiting 352 people in total out of whom 90 female and 106 men additional beneficiaries from income generated from selling of products mainly in trade-fairs.

1. 4 self-employment opportunities further strengthened in four regions of the country for particular poor, marginalized and vulnerable women, particularly the ones that are de jure or de facto heads of households;

Economic and Social Empowerment for Roma and Egyptians - a booster for social inclusion (ESERE)
capital of a political entity
seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: The project works with central and local institutions to boost Roma inclusion

description.narrative:
1. Assessment of the progress made by the Government of Albania in the realisation of the rights of Roma and Egyptian communities.
2. Assessment of progress reported in at least 3-4 priority areas of NAPREI (education, access to social services, employment and VET).

comment.narrative: Roma and Egyptian households more than twice affected by poverty in comparison to non-Roma households living in close proximity.

1. At least 2% increase of registered RE jobseekers participating in EPMs by project completion (2018). 2. At least 4 active ALMs designed tailored to the needs of the RE communities 3. At least 50 RE women and men benefit from ALMS implementation (at least 30% women) 4. At least 50 RE unemployed jobseekers (at least 30% women) participate in nationwide and municipal employment 5. Four local profiling per each intervention area developed in 2016. 6. At least 10 Community Counselling Forums established and functional in all targeted areas. 7. Increased capacities of R/E CSOs. 8. At least 4 Community Upgrading Projects (CUP) with an average value of EUR 75,000 per project set up and implemented. Each of the CUP interventions to be featured in one of the documentaries produced by the project. 9. Set of documents produced on integrated approach and Behaviour Change model (guidelines, toolkit and procedures to implement integrated health, social, and education programmes) prepared, negotiated and adapted by MoSWY. 10. The gap in the proportion of Roma and Egyptian women and men access to basic social services and primary education compared to the majority of the population is reduced by 2%. 11. At least 60% of Roma and Egyptians report improved attitudes of public servants and service providers towards RE communities. 12. Public relation events and promotional materials to highlight programme results. Disaggregated data on Roma and Egyptians available per each sector of the NAPREI 2015-2020. 13. ROMALB data collection system at the national and local level improved, updated and functional. Inter-ministerial Committee for RA inclusion functions effectively. 14. Multi-stakeholder Coordinating Forum established and operational including also experts representing at least 6 different fields of research, as per priorities for RE inclusion in NAPREI 2015-2020. 15. No of challenges identified and policy responses provided at the inter-ministerial meetings.

I. Improved and diversified employment promotion measures developed and provided to Roma and Egyptian women and men enhancing their skills and employability: 1. Employment Mapping completed and available on December 2016. 2. Experts to design the curricula are recruited on December 2016 and work is in progress for curricula design. 3. 48 RE participating in the ESERE Project employment promotion programmes until December 2016. There is an increase by approximately 45% of R/E benefiting from ALMs (107+48=155 R/E participating in NES and ESERE ALM;) 4. 426 R/E registered as unemployed job seekers and mediated for employment., 73 R/E citizens (40M and 33F) employed until December 2016. 5. 4 active ALMMs designed and tailored to the needs of the RE communities by the project in cooperation with NES and being implemented. The measure on entrepreneurship/self-employment and subsidized public work is being developed. 6. 48 R/E citizens benefit from ALMS until December 2016. 7. 73 R/E citizens get employed. II. Increased participation of Roma and Egyptian women and men in local development processes: 8. 50 participants in each training coming from the targeted municipalities (CSOs and R/E activists). 9. Around 18 representatives of organizations and 16 activists increased their knowledge and skills on inclusive development through a series of training. 10. 13 community counselling forums established and operational. 11. Consultation meetings commenced in December 2016. Four meetings were organized during December 2016. 12. 22 community mobilization and self-help activities implemented jointly with LG and R/E community members. III. Improved access to basic and equitable services and inclusiveness of the society in Albania: 13. Need assessment and pilot model of ICBSS available by Nov 2016. ICBSS will be piloted in 4 community centres in 2017. 14. Work has started to prepare a behaviour change model and training curricula which will be completed during 2017. 15. 1st issu

1. At least 2% increase of registered RE jobseekers participating in EPMs by project completion (2018). 2. At least 20 RE citizens (of which 50% women) supported to enter the labour market through the provision of basic literacy life skills training. 3. At least 5 active ALMs designed tailored to the needs of the RE communities 4. At least 202 RE women and men benefit from ALMS implementation (at least 30% women) 5. At least 202 RE unemployed jobseekers (at least 30% women) participate in nationwide and municipal employment promotion programmes. 6. At least 100 staff of NES and other institutions trained (at least 50% women) on the implementation and monitoring EPMs targeting Roma and Egyptian women and men. (Year 1,2At least 4 local employment mediators/coaches trained and 1 national placed at NES offices 7. At least 50% of RE citizens surveyed indicate that NES and other institutions’ staff provide improved services to RE communities. 8. Minimum 20 organisations increase their knowledge and skills on inclusive development through a series of training. 9. 3-year RE Local Community Development Plan in Shkodra and update of existing Plans in compliance with the territorial reform in Tirana, Berat and Durres. 10. At least 10 Community Counselling Forums functional in all targeted areas. 11. Up to 20 projects (5/area), 5000 - 15000 EUR funded and implemented by R/E CSOs. 12. At least 9 Community Upgrading Projects (CUP) with an average value of EUR 75,000 per project set up and implemented. Each of the CUP interventions to be featured in one of the documentaries produced by the project. 13. Minimum 20 community actions/ self-help activities will be generated, selected and implemented in each pilot municipality. 14. Set of documents produced on integrated approach and Behaviour Change model (guidelines, toolkit and procedures to implement integrated health, social, and education programmes) prepared, negotiated and adapted by MoSWY. 15. The gap in the pr

I. Improved and diversified employment promotion measures developed and provided to Roma and Egyptian women and men enhancing their skills and employability: 1. Employment Mapping completed and available on December 2016. 2. Experts to design the curricula are recruited on December 2016 and work is in progress for curricula design. 3. 143 RE participating in the ESERE Project employment promotion programmes until 30 March 2017. 4. 426 R/E registered as unemployed job seekers and mediated for employment. 5. 4 active ALMMs designed and tailored to the needs of the RE communities by the project in cooperation with NES and being implemented. The measure on entrepreneurship/self-employment and subsidized public work is being developed. 6. 146 R/E citizens benefit from ALMS until December 2016. 7. 146 R/E citizens get employed. II. Increased participation of Roma and Egyptian women and men in local development processes: 8. 50 participants in each training coming from the targeted municipalities (CSOs and R/E activists). 9. Around 18 representatives of organisations and 16 activists increased their knowledge and skills on inclusive development through a series of training. 10. 13 community counselling forums established and operational. 11. Consultation meetings continued during 2016-2017. 12. 25 community mobilisation and self-help activities implemented jointly with LG and R/E community members. III. Improved access to basic and equitable services and inclusiveness of the society in Albania: 13. Need assessment and pilot model of ICBSS available by Nov 2016. ICBSS will be piloted in 4 community centres starting in early April 2017. 14. Work has started to prepare a behaviour change model and training curricula which will be completed during 2017. 15. 1st and 2nd issue of the ESERE newsletter prepared. 16. 11 cases of children got birth registered (8 females 3 males) 17. School as community centre model is being applied in 4 elementary schools (Gjon Buzuku/Tirana

description.narrative: Undertake a Initial Mercury Assessment to identify the national mercury challenges and the extent to which legal, policy and regulatory framework will enable Albania to implement future obligations under the Minamata Convention

Initial Mercury Assessment to identify the national mercury challenges and the extent to which legal, policy and regulatory framework will enable Albania to implement future obligations under the Minamata Convention
Anti corruption
Capacity for environmental monitoring and information management in Albania

title.narrative: Cover page CCCD signed and dated

description.narrative: Establishment of Albania’s Environmental Information Management and Monitoring System

The project interventions imply mainly infrastructure rehabilitation such as reconstruction of embankments, dams and river protection; repairing and/or upgrading of damaged irrigation and drainage canals; etc.

The overall objective is to strengthen resilience and disaster risk preparedness and prevention in southeast Albania in line with the post-disaster needs assessment following the February 2015 floods.

No. flood protection built environment restored in priority areas No. studies on disaster social impact and risk scenarios for building national and local capacities to address social and gender-based vulnerabilities and mitigate environmental and economic losses. No. flood protection built environment rehabilitated and put back to operation Assessment of impact of floods on vulnerable groups and their views on ways to cope with such risks. No. studies/reports carried out No. workshops and participants No. infrastructures rehabilitated Study on floods social impact Awareness raising targeting local authorities Vulnerability to climate change and other major disasters assessed for specified vulnerable groups, including gender considerations

comment.narrative: Obsolete, poorly maintained and damaged flood protection infrastructures Lack of technical studies and thus preparedness to cope with future risks and integrate such considerations into development agendas. Key flood protection infrastructures damaged, exposing about 26,000 ha of agricultural land at risk for next rainy season. PDNA 2015 No prior social assessment on floods impact with such a disaggregation detail; no inputs to local decision making from this angle.

17 urgent infrastructure interventions contracted out
Half of infrastructure interventions completed

17 prioritized as most urgent interventions have been grouped in lots and tendered out to construction companies Contracts with all construction and corresponding supervision and testing commissioning companies in place All resources needed to achieve specific objective 1 are in place, including human and financial At least half of infrastructure interventions are completed

All urgent infrastructure interventions finished and handed over to beneficiaries
A report on the social impact of the floods submitted
4 reports on social vulnerabilities and Disaster risk scenarios submitted

All urgent infrastructure interventions finished before the rainy season / autumn and the supervision reports and testing and commissioning reports submitted All completed infrastructure interventions have been handed over to beneficiaries
One assessment report on social impact of floods focusing on four municipalities has been completed and presented to stakeholders and beneficiaries
Four technical reports / assessments on social vulnerabilities and Disaster risk scenarios developed, submitted and presented to beneficiaries

One additional infrastructure intervention finished
Two remaining Infrastructure works handed over to beneficiaries
One final workshop is organized presenting the completed 4 reports on social vulnerabilities and Disaster risk scenarios to beneficiaries

All completed infrastructure interventions, including the existing and additional ones, are handed over to beneficiaries and continue to be resilient as intended
All flood-affected communities are aware of the effects of climate change and natural hazards
The project is successfully closed

description.narrative: The project is developed in line and continuity of the results of its predecessor STAR as well as in complementarity with the assistance of various partners for strengthening the institutional and administrative capacities at local level.

participating-org.narrative: UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID)

title.narrative: STAR2 Progress Report No1 Jul Oct 2016 FINAL

description.narrative: STAR2 main components are: (1) Strengthening institutional and administrative capacities of LGUs; (2) Improving service delivery at LGUs level; and (3) Increasing good governance through citizen oriented and meaningful participatory decision-making.

description.narrative: Construction of a new Accommodation Center for Asylum Seekers on behalf of UNHCR Albania
The purpose of this project is to support UNHCR Albania for the construction of a new Accommodation Center for Asylum Seekers in the suburbs of Tirana.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - policy, planning and administration
#of reception centre buildings/structures established

comment.narrative: Reception/ transit centre infrastructure established and maintained

Preparation of Design and BoQ Preparation of Bidding Package documents Bidding Process Work-plan and schedule preparation Setup a management committee Cleaning of site from existing buildings Concrete work from ground to third floor
Tendering works and completion of four floors concrete structure by end December 2016
Completion of the new accommodation building at the Babrru Centre. Testing and Commissioning Services for the new building
Construction of the new accommodation center for the asylum seekers in Babrru - completed. Testing and Commissioning of the new building - completed.

description.narrative: 1. New Social Protection and Inclusion Strategy, and ME Frameworks developed in a participatory way 2. Number of new laws and secondary legislation supported to ensure conformity with the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. 3. Number of municipalities planning, budgeting and providing gender sensitive social services to most at risk populations 4. Number of policies and plans on social services developed or improved with participation of Civil Society Organizations and marginalized groups 5. Number of regional coordination committees established for participatory social impact assessment 6. Criteria and guidelines in place for adapting social and public services to the specific needs of Roma/Egyptian populations

comment.narrative: 1. National social protection and social inclusion strategies due to expire in 2013 2. No laws and secondary legislation in place; concept of accessibility not understood as a cross-cutting issue 3. Number of Local Government units with inclusive social policy services in place is not known 4. No regional coordination committees for participatory social impact assessment 5. No Criteria and guidelines in place for adapting social services to the specific needs of Roma/Egyptian populations

1. SI Policy Document 2016 – 2020; 2. Social Housing Strategy 3. Assessment of housing living conditions of Roma settlement needs for upgrading interventions 4. Feasibility studies for social housing in two Municipalities – Tirana Durres 5. Inclusive local plans developed for PwD in on local government unit 6. Social Inclusion action plans in at least 2 local government units 7. 4 demonstrative projects for PWD other vulnerable groups. (Tirana, Pogradec, Saranda Bulqiza) 8. Local NGOs provide services to persons with disabilities enabled to provide professional support, and assess monitor the implementation of the rights of PwD

1. SI Policy Document 2016 – 2020 developed and endorsed by the government 2. Handbook of jurisprudence standards developed by the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) on the rights of PwD is guiding the implementation of the CRPD by Albanian judiciary system other legal professionals. 3. Study on independent living supported decision-making for PwD 4. Concept note, the Guidelines Work plan on establishment running of the Statistical Indicators Integrity Group - (SIIG). The SIPD glossary developed. 5. The new law on Social Housing drafted consulted 6. Establishment of a reliable system for collecting updating housing needs data at national local level; 140 housing specialists from 61 municipalities on how to implement social housing programmes and coordinate social housing operations 7. Inclusive local plans developed for PwD in Saranda 8. 106 central and local government disability focal points and officials from regional SSS and 226 public social service providers are trained on issues such as disability rights and implementation of related legislation; mainstreaming disability in the national and local policies and on service delivery 9. Social Inclusion action plans in 3 local government units are developed 10. 4 direct demonstrative projects for PWD other vulnerable groups. At least 200 children aged 6 – 18 to access quality social care education services as per their specific needs. (Blind Students institute, Pogradec, Saranda Bulqiza development centres) 11. 6 Local Disabled People's Organisations provide services to PWD 12. 220 in-service judges and prosecutors received training on UNCRPD requirements and the ECtHR standards and the rights of persons with disabilities 13. Access to justice is advocated and implemented from UNDP in partnership with national NGOs. Free legal aid services to 309 R/E families in 6 municipalities: Korca, Berat, Cerrik, Lushnja, Tirana, Shkodra, Durres. 14. 92 R/E youngsters supported with adminis

1. Capacities of the Ministry of Social Welfare and Youth enhanced to carry out its mandate to monitor and coordinate the adoption of social inclusion and gender equality targets by line ministries and local authorities. 2. Completion and handover to local authorities of the demonstrative projects developed and implemented to accommodate the needs of persons with disabilities in the Municipalities of Pogradec, Saranda, Bulqiza and Shijak. 3. Assessment of housing living conditions and investment needs of Roma communities completed. Two reports on feasibility studies for social housing in Municipalities of Tirana and Durres are finalized; 18 assessment reports on housing living conditions of Roma and Egyptians in Albania finalised and presented in a round table with participation of representatives from 61 municipalities and the Minister of Urban Development. 4. The draft Law on Social Housing drafted with support by UNSSIA programme approved by the Council of Minister in April 2017. 5. Six associations of persons with disabilities assisted with micro-grants to implement projects aiming at strengthening their own capacities on advocacy for disability rights, partnering and networking. 230 teachers and assistant teachers introduced to the situation of children with disabilities in the education system; 3 booklets/ manual produced; 210 people with disabilities benefited from awareness/training sessions and conferences organized.

description.narrative: Modernize and strengthen the Albanian university system, intervening in certain structural deficiencies in order to put educational and administrative management online and link it to the European University and research network
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions

comment.narrative: a) 0 Higher education law approved in 2015 b) 2 existing agencies c) 0 Universities
a) 33 bylaws and instructions drafted and approved b) 5 agencies (3 newly established and 2 re-organized) c) 35 universities that complete their statutes
a) 33 bylaws and instructions drafted and approved b) 5 agencies (3 newly established and 2 re-organized) c) 35 universities that complete their statutes
